Award.AwardTitle: EAGER proposal: Consequences of Environmental Stress-induced Epigenomes on Mutation and Organismal Fitness
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mutations are the ultimate source of all genetic variation. How organisms interact with the environment to influence the processes that generate mutations is therefore, critical for understanding the origin of all evolutionary change. Scientists are rapidly discovering the integrative role the epigenome, defined as chemical compounds that interact with DNA to modify gene function, plays in mediating responses between the environment and the expression of individual traits. However, the molecular events that underlie these environmentally governed controls remain virtually unknown. This research is designed to characterize the influence of environment induced epigenetic state on the frequency, types and genetic location of mutations to better understand their influence on the health and fitness of organisms, populations, and evolution. The waterflea, Daphnia pulex, offers a unique opportunity for these studies, because it is well established as a model of environmental stress, its genome is well characterized, and its reproductive strategy that includes clonal reproduction allows for control of both genetic and epigenetic background. This research through outreach programs at both Indiana University and Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory will benefit the development of young scientist, especially related to the novel bioinformatics and computational approaches that will be developed in this proposal. The knowledge gained through this research stands to have profound implications for society and the long-term health of populations, which are living longer in the presence of a large diversity of chemicals that can modify DNA.

This research will leverage preexisting D. pulex mutation accumulation (MA) lines bottlenecked ~10,000 total generations and propagated in the presence and absence of cadmium. Cadmium is used here as a model environmental stressor, because it is a powerful mutagen in spite of not interacting directly with DNA, and it has been shown to profoundly affect heritable chromatin packaging and epigenetic state of DNA. However, it is expected that the epigenetic affects due to cadmium and the subsequent influence on mutation will be generalizable across any stressor. These MA lines have already undergone whole genome sequencing, the spectra of all mutations (de novo copy number variants, base-substitution mutations, and gene conversion processes) are established, their fitness quantified over the course of multiple generations, and the mutational consequences on fitness determined. The goals of this research are to: 1) determine the environment's influence on DNA packaging by identifying nucleosome occupancy within chromatin from individual MA lines, 2) characterize the role of stress on epigenetic state by identifying stress induced post-translational modifications of histones, and 3) investigate the role epigenetic state plays in regulating access to the genome, thereby potentiating mutations, and influencing organismal fitness. Thus, these studies will elucidate how the epigenome communicates with the genome to provide an interface between the genome and the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mutations are the source of all genetic variation and understanding how organisms interact with the environment to influence the processes that generate mutations is critical for understanding the origin of all evolutionary change. To this end, scientists are rapidly discovering the integrative role the epigenome, defined as heritable chemical modifications of chromatin that interact with DNA to modify gene functions, plays in mediating responses between the environment and the expression of individual traits. However, the molecular events that underlie these environmentally governed controls remain largely unknown. Thus, this project characterized the influence of environment induced epigenetic state on the frequency, types and genetic location of mutations to better understand their influence on the health and fitness of organisms, populations, and in driving evolution.

 

The waterflea, Daphnia pulex, offers a unique opportunity for these studies, because it is a well-established model of environmental stress, and its reproductive strategy that includes clonal reproduction, allows for control of both genetic and epigenetic history. This research leverages preexisting D. pulex mutation accumulation (MA) lines each bottlenecked for 80 generations (~10,000 total generational events) and developed in the presence and absence of cadmium. Cadmium was used as a model environmental stressor because it is a powerful mutagen, in spite of not interacting directly with DNA, and it has been shown to profoundly affect heritable chromatin packaging and epigenetic state of DNA. However, it is expected that cadmium’s epigenetic controls on mutation will be generalizable across many stressors.

 

Our goals of this research were to: 1) determine the environment’s (i.e., with and without the environmental stressor cadmium) influence on DNA packaging by identifying nucleosome occupancy within chromatin from individual MA lines, 2) characterize the role of stress on epigenetic state by identifying cadmium induced post-translational modifications of histones, which comprise the nucleosome core, and 3) investigate the role epigenetic state plays in regulating access to the genome, potentiating mutations, and influencing organismal fitness by quantitatively linking nucleosome occupancy and the prevalence of specific histone modifications with the already determined mutational spectra and fitness levels of the individual MA lines.

 

To achieve these goals we mapped nucleosome position in Daphnia and determined that oxidative stress shifts the distribution of mutation with respect to nucleosome position. We also determined that cadmium/oxidative stress alters the rate, distribution, and spectra of mutations. We observe that oxidative stress alters epigenetic state (e.g., histone modifications), and alters the methylation status of DNA, which in turn influences the rate of GC->CG mutations. We also observe that the breakpoints of structural mutations, especially large insertion and deletions are flanked by histone modification (H3K4me3). Collectively, these studies begin to elucidate how the epigenome provides an interface between the genome and the environment. This knowledge stands to have profound implications for society and the long-term health of populations, which are living longer in the presence of increasing concentration and growing diversity of chemicals that can modify DNA through induced epigenetic states.

 

High school, undergraduate, and graduate students have participated in this research through outreach programs at Indiana University, the Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory, and the University of Birmingham, UK. The main outlet for these broader impacts is the Workshop in Environmental genomics that is held annually both in Maine and in the United Kingdom, which has used data generated from this grant in a module that trains these participants in the novel bioinformatics and computational approaches developed from this project.
